drugs: Haemophilus B Conjugate and Hepatitis B Vaccine

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Haemophilus B Conjugate and Hepatitis B Vaccine

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in infants younger than 6 weeks of age and older than 15 months
  • Haemophilus influenza B and hepatitis B vaccination: (hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)-negative mother) 0.5 mL IM x 3 doses given at 2, 4, and 12 to 15 months of age (at least a 6-week interval between doses 1 and 2 and an 8- to 11-month interval between doses 2 and 3).

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Haemophilus influenza B and hepatitis B vaccination

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• age less than 6 weeks; reduced immune response and potential for immune tolerance to future injections
  • hypersensitivity to yeast, to any component of the vaccine (manufacturer); allergic reaction, severe (eg, anaphylaxis) after a previous dose or to a vaccine component
  • symptoms suggestive of hypersensitivity after vaccination with the vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • adults; not recommended for use
  • bleeding disorders (eg, hemophilia, thrombocytopenia); take proper precautions to avoid hematoma risk following vaccination
  • hypersensitivity reaction, including anaphylaxis may occur
  • immunocompromised patients, including those with malignancies or receiving immunosuppressive drugs; diminished immune response may occur; consider deferring vaccination in patients on immunosuppressive therapy
  • IM administration only; avoid injecting into a blood vessel
  • latex sensitivity; vial stopper contains dry, natural latex rubber
  • report suspected adverse events to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (22.4% to 27.2%), Injection site pain (23.9% to 34.5%), Swelling at injection site (27.2% to 30.4%)
  • Neurologic:Somnolence (21.1% to 49.5%)
  • Psychiatric:Crying, Prolonged (0.2% to 2.4%), Crying, Unusual, High-Pitched (2.9% to 10.6%), Irritability (32.2% to 57%)
  • Other:Fever (10.5% to 14.2%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Febrile seizure, Seizure

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The combination haemophilus b conjugate (meningococcal protein conjugate) and hepatitis B (recombinant) vaccine (Comvax(R)) is a bivalent vaccine containing antigenic components of the haemophilus influenza type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate) covalently bound to an outer membrane protein complex of Neisseria meningitidis and hepatitis B surface antigen from recombinant yeast cultures. Comvax(R) works by inducing protective antibodies to haemophilus influenza type b infection and all known subtypes of hepatitis B virus.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    IM use only; do not inject IV, intradermally, or subQ
  • Intramuscular
    • shake well before use
    • inject into anterolateral aspect of the thigh
    • may be administered concomitantly with diphtheria, tetanus, whole-cell pertussis vaccine (DTP); diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP); oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV); inactivated poliomyelitis vaccine (IPV); mumps, measles, and rubella vaccine (MMR); and varicella virus vaccine, live

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: no specific monitoring has been determined

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Comvax
Intramuscular Suspension: (Haemophilus B Conjugate Vaccine - Hepatitis B Vaccine Recombinant) 7.5 MCG/0.5 ML-5 MCG/0.5 ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause injection site reactions, somnolence, irritability, and fever.
  • Review dosing schedule with caregiver.
  • Inform caregiver of the importance of the child receiving the entire series of vaccinations. If a dose is missed, another appointment should be scheduled as soon as possible.
